    Format translator

    Michael D. Sumner

    2017-09-08

    There are three low-level elements in planar shapes, they are coordinates, paths, and objects.

    Consider a minimal pair of polygons, they share one side and one has a hole.

    library(silicate)
str(minimal_mesh$geom)
    ## List of 2
##  $ :List of 1
##   ..$ :List of 2
##   .. ..$ : num [1:8, 1:2] 0 0 0.75 1 0.5 0.8 0.69 0 0 1 ...
##   .. .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
##   .. .. .. ..$ : NULL
##   .. .. .. ..$ : chr [1:2] "x" "y"
##   .. ..$ : num [1:6, 1:2] 0.2 0.5 0.5 0.3 0.2 0.2 0.2 0.2 0.4 0.6 ...
##   .. .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
##   .. .. .. ..$ : NULL
##   .. .. .. ..$ : chr [1:2] "x" "y"
##   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr [1:3] "XY" "MULTIPOLYGON" "sfg"
##  $ :List of 1
##   ..$ :List of 1
##   .. ..$ : num [1:5, 1:2] 0.69 0.8 1.1 1.23 0.69 0 0.6 0.63 0.3 0
##   .. .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
##   .. .. .. ..$ : NULL
##   .. .. .. ..$ : chr [1:2] "x" "y"
##   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr [1:3] "XY" "MULTIPOLYGON" "sfg"
##  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "sfc_MULTIPOLYGON" "sfc"
##  - attr(*, "precision")= num 0
##  - attr(*, "bbox")=Class 'bbox'  Named num [1:4] 0 0 1.23 1
##   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:4] "xmin" "ymin" "xmax" "ymax"
##  - attr(*, "crs")=List of 2
##   ..$ epsg       : int NA
##   ..$ proj4string: chr NA
##   ..- attr(*, "class")= chr "crs"
##  - attr(*, "n_empty")= int 0

    The first lower level element is the coordinates, and in this case there are 19 x,y pairs.

    sc_coord(minimal_mesh)
    ## # A tibble: 19 x 2
##       x_    y_
##    <dbl> <dbl>
##  1  0.00  0.00
##  2  0.00  1.00
##  3  0.75  1.00
##  4  1.00  0.80
##  5  0.50  0.70
##  6  0.80  0.60
##  7  0.69  0.00
##  8  0.00  0.00
##  9  0.20  0.20
## 10  0.50  0.20
## 11  0.50  0.40
## 12  0.30  0.60
## 13  0.20  0.40
## 14  0.20  0.20
## 15  0.69  0.00
## 16  0.80  0.60
## 17  1.10  0.63
## 18  1.23  0.30
## 19  0.69  0.00

    The second is the paths, we can see these three above in the hierarchical structure, but it’s hard to see how many and how they relate.

    sc_path(minimal_mesh)
    ## # A tibble: 3 x 6
##    ncol         type subobject   object     path ncoords_
##   <int>        <chr>     <int>    <chr>    <chr>    <int>
## 1     2 MULTIPOLYGON         1 b05606e9 c8e03c7e        8
## 2     2 MULTIPOLYGON         1 b05606e9 3a849f88        6
## 3     2 MULTIPOLYGON         1 fe171c0d b0f3a18a        5

    Finally, is the objects - this is a top-level grouping for the structured shapes.

    sc_object(minimal_mesh)
    ## # A tibble: 2 x 1
##       a
## * <int>
## 1     1
## 2     2

    What is the point of having these elements in this decomposed form?

    Conversions

    We can use the decomposed forms to generate other forms. Here we simply visit every path with the polygon function.

    path <- sc_path(minimal_mesh)
coord <- sc_coord(minimal_mesh)
plot(coord)
lapply(split(seq_len(sum(path$ncoords_)), rep(path$path, path$ncoords_)), 
       function(i) polygon(sc_coord(minimal_mesh)[i, ]))

    ## $`3fd27f2b`
## NULL
## 
## $`4403605a`
## NULL
## 
## $`9900d755`
## NULL

    That looks ok, but what if we want to know it’s really a hole? We ignored the fact that there are two polygons, and one has a hole.
